channel.title: My Blog
channel.description: Resources and news in the areas of human rights, genocide, and world history

item.title: Foundations of the Modern World
item.description: In California, tenth grade world history courses are usually begun by a review of the foundations of world civilization. This enormous topic is then reduced, by necessity, to a quick overview of global religions and a summary of the European Enlightenment. I have put together a list of books on these topics, on the page Bibliography of Intellectual & Ethical Foundations of the Modern Era, and I plan to add to it more global perspectives as I find them and as they are suggested to me.

item.title: Globalization in World History
item.description: There are few words in modern political discussion tossed around more freely and are so misunderstood. Here is a beginning reading list to get a handle on the enormously popular topic: Bibliography of Globalization.

item.title: Teaching History
item.description:
When I was teaching, I spent dozens of hours searching for texts that would help me be a more creative teacher. I remembered how, as a high school student, I had learned well from lecture, but most of my classmates had not. I hated how everyone who heard that I taught history said that it had been their least favorite class. I wanted to be better, to help students see the impact of history on our daily lives, the danger of ignorance, and how crucial history was to understanding so many other disciplines. History has the drama that can be found in literature, the logic that can be found in science, and the creativity that can be found in writing and arguing. I’ve put together a list of texts that will hopefully be of use to other world history teachers here: Bibliography of Teaching History.

I’ve also updated the descriptions on the page Links for Teacher Training & Organizations to reflect my experiences with each. These are definitely the best!

item.title: Commodity Histories
item.description: I love commodity and thematic histories. These are the books that you can read and learn about economics, culture, individuals, groups, international and domestic politics, changing tastes, status symbols, classes, science . . . the list goes on. The page Bibliography of Thematic & Commodity Histories has a list of books on topics including salt, diamonds and oil, among many others.

item.title: Bangladesh Genocide
item.description:
In 1971, a genocide started that claimed up to three million people, though estimates range as low as 200,000. Eight to ten million others fled the country to find safety. A short starting list is here: Bibliography of the Bangladesh Genocide.
(On a side note, with the posting of this page, all of the bibliographies dealing with genocide and mass murder now have initial content on them. Yay!)

item.title: East Timor
item.description: Indonesia occupied East Timor from 1975 until 1999, with final realization of independence in 2002. Torture, starvation, massacre and summary executions were suffered for twenty five years. Out of a population of less than one-million, the East Timorese are estimated to have lost more than 100,000. A short reading list can be found on the Bibliography of the East Timor Genocide page.

item.title: Indonesian Massacres
item.description: These massive killings, meant to rid the country of communist revolutionaries, were the method in which Suharto began his thirty-year rule as president of Indonesia. More than 500,000 are estimated to have been killed, while more than a million were imprisoned at one point or another. So far, I have only found a single monograph, listed on the Bibliography of the Indonesian Massacres page, but the number of sources there will undoubtedly be added to as I receive suggestions.

item.title: Burundi
item.description: In 1972, 80-210,000 Tutsi were killed by Hutu. In 1993, approximately 50,000 Hutu were killed by Tutsi. I have put together a small introductory reading list on the Bibliography of the Burundi Genocide page.

item.title: Al-Anfal Campaign
item.description: Between 1986 and 1989, the Iraqi regime in Baghdad led a campaign against the Kurdish people of the north. Using bombing, deportations, mass executions, destruction of villages and chemical warfare, they are estimated to have killed 100-150,000 and displaced approximately one million people. Here is a reading list to begin to understand what happened there: Bibliography of Ethnic Cleansing in Iraq.

item.title: Genocide of the Hereros and Nama
item.description: I’ve posted a short Bibliography of the Genocide of the Herero & Nama. The genocide of the Herero and Nama is often seen as the precursor to many of the strategies of the Nazis.
